document.docTitle: Description of a new flower fly species of the Copestylum vagum group (Diptera Syrphidae) from pristine Amazonian rainforests of Colombia and Suriname

emphasis.docTitle:
Description of a new flower fly species of the
Copestylum vagum
group ( Diptera : Syrphidae ) from pristine Amazonian rainforests of Colombia and Suriname

subSection.paragraph:
AUGUSTO LEÓN MONTOYA 1,* ,
HENRY MAURICIO PARADA-MARÍN
2,3 & YARDANY RAMOS-PASTRANA 1,2,4

docAuthorAffiliation.emphasis: Universidad de Antioquia , Instituto de Biología, Grupo de Entomología – GEAU, Calle 67 53-108, AA 1226 Medellín, Colombia .

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Universidad de la Amazonia, Grupo de Investigación en Entomología Universidad de la Amazonia -GIEU-, Laboratório de Entomologia, Av, 11 5-69 Juan XXIII, Florencia, Caquetá , Colombia .

subSection.paragraph:
3
�
h.parada@udla.edu.co ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-5387-4495

4
� ya.ramos@udla.edu.co; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3193-6659

* Corresponding author.
� aleon.montoya@udea.edu.co

The adult stage of a new flower fly species,
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
( Diptera : Syrphidae ) is described based on a single male collected in pristine rainforest in the Amazonian region of Colombia (type-locality: Florencia, Caquetá ) and two females from a conserved forest in Suriname ( Para and Brokopondo ).
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
belongs to the
C. vagum
species group and is similar in appearance to
Copestylum vagum (Wiedemann)
,
C. musicanum (Curran)
,
C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
, and
C. chapadensis (Curran)
from which it differs by the gena and face separated by a very broad brown vitta; scutum orange except for the wide medial vitta, which is dark and metallic, ending before the prescutellar region, with the apical margin M-shaped; tibiae dark-brown, except yellow on basal 1/4. The male genitalia of
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
are unique and striking among the
C. vagum
species group, characterized by the epandrium and cercus black, contrasting with the colour of hypandrium and surstylus, which are orange; epandrium with a dorsal extension, a novel character among this species group, in addition to the L-shaped surstylus, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to a small deer antler in velvet. Images of type material, including photographs of male genitalia are provided. A comparison of the diagnostic characters is provided as well as modifications to the previous keys to distinguish
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
from the other species of the
C. vagum
group. The species
Copestylum araceorum Ricarte & Rotheray
and
C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
are recorded for the first time in the Amazonian rainforest in Colombia .
Key words: Eristalinae , Volucellini, Neotropics , identification key

El estado adulto de una nueva especie de moscas de las flores,
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
( Diptera : Syrphidae ) es descrito a partir de un único macho recolectado en un bosque lluvioso prístino en la región amazónica de Colombia (Localidad tipo: Florencia, Caquetá ) y dos hembras de bosque primario de Surinam ( Para y Brokopondo ).
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
pertenece al grupo de especies
C. vagum
, y es similar en apariencia a
Copestylum vagum (Wiedemann)
,
C. musicanum (Curran)
,
C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
, and
C. chapadensis (Curran)
de las cuales se diferencia por la gena y cara separados por una vita marrón muy ancha; escudo torácico naranja a excepción de la vita media ancha de color oscuro y metálico que termina antes de la región prescutelar, con el margen apical en forma de M; tibias marrón oscuro, excepto su 1/4 basal amarillo. La genitalia masculina de
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
es única y sorprendente entre las especies del grupo
C. vagum
, caracterizada por el epandrio y los cercos negros, que contrastan con el color del hipandrio y los surestilos, que son de color naranja; epandrio con extensión dorsal, un carácter novedoso dentro de este grupo de especies, además del surestilo en forma de L, con dos pares de crestas redondeadas en el borde dorsal, similar a unas pequeñas astas de ciervo aterciopeladas. Se proporcionan imágenes del material tipo, incluyendo fotografías de la genitalia masculina. Se proporciona una comparación de los caracteres diagnósticos, así como modificaciones a las claves anteriores para distinguir
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
de las otras especies del grupo
C. vagum
. Las especies
Copestylum araceorum Ricarte & Rotheray
y
C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
son registradas por primera vez en la región Amazónica Colombiana.
Palabras claves: Eristalinae , Volucellini, Neotrópico , clave de identificación.

The genus
Copestylum Macquart, 1846
( Diptera : Syrphidae : Eristalinae : Volucellini ) is by far the largest Neotropical radiation of Flower flies, with 400+ known species and it is likely that many more species are yet to be discovered and described ( Marinoni & Thompson 2003 ;
Rotheray et al . 2007
;
Montoya et al . 2012
; Montoya 2016 ).

In Colombia , the fauna of
Copestylum
is composed of 68 recorded species, in addition to fourteen species recognized as new to science but still undescribed. The genus is distributed in almost every thermal level from the high altitude paramos down to sea level, reaching the greatest diversity in the Andean and Amazonian regions of the country ( Restrepo-Ortiz & Carrejo 2009 ;
Montoya et al . 2012
; Montoya 2016 ).
Copestylum
is also diverse in Suriname , including 21 recorded species, in addition to six morphospecies denoted as SUR[ Suriname ] by Reemer (2016) . A total of 107 species of
Copestylum
have been recorded in the Brazilian Amazon ( Miranda 2017 ).

Larval stages of
Copestylum
are filter-feeding on microbes from detritus, developing on a huge array of aquatic or semi-aquatic environments rich in decaying plant materials, accelerating tissue recycling rates and water purification ( Seifert & Seifert 1979 ;
Rotheray et al . 2007
, 2009 ;
Ricarte et al . 2015
; Reemer 2016 ).

The diagnostic features to distinguish
Copestylum
from other related genera have been established by Thompson (1981) ,
Rotheray et al . (2007)
, and
Ricarte et al . (2015)
. Within
Copestylum
, the
C. vagum
group includes eighteen species:
Copestylum araceorum Ricarte & Rotheray
in
Ricarte et al. 2015
,
Copestylum bequaerti Curran, 1930
,
Copestylum brevifacies ( Curran, 1926 )
,
Copestylum chapadensis ( Curran, 1930 )
,
Copestylum circe ( Curran, 1939 )
,
Copestylum curiosum ( Curran, 1939 )
,
Copestylum cyclops Ricarte & Hancock
in
Ricarte et al. 2015
,
Copestylum flukei ( Curran, 1936 )
,
Copestylum lanei ( Curran, 1936 )
,
Copestylum mocanum ( Curran, 1936 )
,
Copestylum musicanum ( Curran, 1930 )
,
Copestylum rurale ( Curran, 1939 )
,
Copestylum tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
in
Ricarte et al. 2015
,
Copestylum tigrinum Ricarte & Hancock
in
Ricarte et al. 2015
,
Copestylum vagum ( Wiedemann, 1830 )
,
Copestylum varichaeta ( Curran, 1925 )
,
Copestylum virescens ( Williston, 1891 )
, and
Copestylum willistoni Ricarte & Hancock
in
Ricarte et al. 2015
( Thompson 2006 ;
Ricarte et al. 2015
).

Charles Curran ( Curran 1930 , 1939 ) was the first to key out the
Copestylum species
belonging to the
C. vagum
group, including the description of ten new species. The
C. vagum
group was partially reviewed by
Ricarte et al . (2015)
, including the descriptions and keys to both adult and early stages of seven species, five of which were described as new. In his study, Antonio Ricarte and collaborators suggested an apparent affinity of this group for decomposing fruits as preferred breeding sites.

The present work aims to describe a new
Copestylum species
belonging to the
C. vagum
group from the pristine rainforest in the Amazonian region of Colombia and Suriname .A comparison of the diagnostic characters is provided as well as modifications to the previous keys to distinguish the new species from the other species of the
C. vagum
group.

The morphological terminology follows Cumming and Wood (2017) and
Ricarte et al . (2015)
. The type series of the new species is comprised of dry pinned specimens. The male holotype is deposited at the Colección del Laboratorio de Entomología Universidad de la Amazonia ( LEUA ), Florencia, Caquetá , Colombia . Two female paratypes are deposited in the National Museum of Natural History, Leiden (RMNH), The Netherlands . The types were collected in the lowland Amazonian rainforest of Colombia and Suriname .

To illustrate the morphological characteristics of the herein described species, habitus photographs were created from a series of high-resolution pictures taken at different focal depths using a Leica digital camera DFC450 coupled to a stereomicroscope Leica M205A and connected to a computer with Leica Application Suite software, with an automatic mounting module (synchronization software) (http://www.syncroscopy.com/syncroscopy/). Editing was conducted in Adobe Photoshop CC, and the final image plates were prepared in Illustrator CC, including the scale bar.

For morphological descriptions, adult body length was measured from the tip of the frontal prominence to the posterior end of the abdomen; wing length was measured from wing insertion to the wing apex. Measurements were made using a stereomicroscope Leica M205A equipped with a stereoscope grid.

For the study of the male genitalia, the structure was placed in lactic acid (85%) and heated at 150ºC over a Thermo Scientific Cimarec plate for approximately one hour prior to the dissection. The dissected pieces were photographed in dehydrated glycerin using an excavated slide. After examination, the dissected genitalia were stored in plastic microvials containing glycerin, pinned along with the respective specimen.

Locality and identification labels are enclosed within a double quotation (“ ”), and line breaks of the labels are separated by a forward slash (/). Handwritten information on the labels is provided in italics.

Maps of geographic distribution were plotted using the Simple Mappr software ( Shorthouse 2010 ). Pictures of type specimens of
C. bequaerti
,
C. brevifacies
,
C. chapadensis
,
C. circe
,
C. curiosum
,
C. flukei
,
C. lanei
,
C. musicanum ,
and
C. rurale
are available on the AMNH website for comparison (http://research.amnh.org/invertzoo/ types _db/).
Valid names were taken from the Nomenclator of the BioSystematic Database of World Diptera and Systema Dipterorum ( Evenhuis & Pape 2020 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis (adapted from Thompson 2006 and
Ricarte et al . 2015
). The
C. vagum
group can be distinguished from the other
Copestylum species
groups by: 1) face vittate but not tomentose and with background colour shiny yellow, green, or orange, 2) face not particularly extended, 3) scutum with mixed length pile, not forming distinct layers and most orientated posteriorly, 4) no outstanding, long, thick setae along the rear margin of the scutum, although long pile may be present, 5) apex of the scutellum with a linear depression, 6) calypter dark, brown to black or with brown border, 7) tergum 1 and most of tergum 2 with a pale mark contrasting with the colour of the scutum, scutellum and the rest of the abdomen, and 8) male genitalia with aedeagal hood projecting ventrally from the hypandrium, superior lobe with smooth margins.

Remarks. The new species here described agrees with the diagnostic characters proposed for the
C. vagum
group, but can easily be recognized within this group by the unique and striking male genitalia, characterized by the epandrium and cercus black; epandrium with a dorsal extension, a novel character among the group, in addition to the surstylus L-shaped, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to small deer antlers in velvet.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
, male, holotype (LEUA–00000035890): A. Head, frontal view; B. Habitus, dorsal view; C. Thorax, dorsal view, detail of maculae and pile patterns on scutum; D. Lateral view, E. Latero-posterior view, detail of male genitalia.

FIGURE 3.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
, female, paratype (RMNH-collection). A. Head, frontal view; B. Head, lateral view, C. Habitus, lateral view; D. Thorax and abdomen, dorsal view.

TABLE 1. Morphological differences between males of
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
and similar species of the
Copestylum vagum
group.

tr.td: Strong and wide, wider than the gena
Very wide and of uniform width

tr.th: Thorax Dorsal margin of male eyes

tr.td: Orange except for the wide medial vitta, which is dark and metallic, ending before the prescutellar region, with the apical margin M-shaped
Orange except for yellow anterior and lateral margins, the middle region from scutum to scutellum dark and metallic
Dark greenish-orange with a central, brown prescutellar macula and similar coloured maculae on the scutum
Orange except for yellow anterior and lateral margins and brown prescutellar macula and two brown, medial vitta ending before the transverse suture
Orange with a brown macula reaching the scutellar region, scutellar depression black
Extensively yellow except slightly darkened on the katatergum
Orange except for black or blackened apex
Dark-brown, except yellow on basal 1/4, black pilose on these areas
Tarsomeres 1 and 2 orange, tarsomeres 3–5 black, black pilose
Basitarsomere orange, tarsomeres 3–5 black, black pilose
Basotarsomere of meso- and metalegs contrastingly pale, black pilose
Terga 2–4 yellow, brownish infuscated apically; Terga 3–4 black pilose on apical margin
Terga 2–4 yellow except for a black apex; Tergum 4 white pilose
Terga 2–4 greenish-orange except for a black apex; Terga 3–4 black pilose
Tergum 2 yellow except for black posterior margin; Terga 3–4 black, black pilose
Terga 2–4 yellow except black posteriorly; pile short, black, yellow in front of the first black band, on lateral margins, and the broad base of tergum 4. Tergum 5 wholly black
Orange, variable in shape, usually slightly longer than basally wide
Orange, tapered and about as long as basally wide
Orange, L-shaped, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge
Subrectangular abruptly indented below the middle
L-shaped, basal section longer than the apical section
Hook-shaped, with a kinked apex strongly curved downward
Hook-shaped and curved unevenly with a longer section above the base and tapering to a point
With a kinked apex strongly curved downward

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. A. Habitat of
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
in a pristine forest at Florencia, Caquetá in Colombia. The specimens were collected using a canopy Malaise trap (Rafael & Gorayeb 1982); B. Geographical distribution map showing the collection localities of
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
in the Amazon rainforest of Colombia and Suriname (Red triangle).

heading.emphasis:
Additional records of species of the
Copestylum vagum
group

subSubSection.paragraph:
New distributional records of
C. tenorium
and
C. araceorum
are here provided.
Copestylum tenorium
was exclusively known from Costa Rica and
C. araceorum
was described from material collected in Costa Rica and Ecuador . Both species are recorded for the first time in the Amazonian rainforest of Colombia .

heading.emphasis:
Adjustments to existing identification keys of the
C. vagum
species group

subSubSection.paragraph:
The last key of Curran (1930 , 1939 ) covered most of the species included in the
C. vagum
group.
Ricarte et al . (2015)
partially reviewed the
C. vagum
group, providing a key for seven species, of which five were described as new. We provide modifications to the previous keys of the
C. vagum
group to distinguish
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
from the other eighteen species included in the group. The new key is based on characters provided by Curran (1930 , 1939 ), Thompson (2006) , and Ricarte et al. (2015) , in addition to some new provided here. Images and information of type specimens of nine species (see material and methods) are available at the AMNH website.

heading.emphasis:
Description of a new species of the
Copestylum vagum
group

subSubSection.paragraph:
Copestylum
SUR-04 in Reemer (2016) Type material.
HOLOTYPE .
Adult male, pinned, deposited at the LEUA collection. Original label: “ COLOMBIA , Caquetá , Florencia, Vda.[Vereda] Paraíso, Fca.[Finca] Paraíso” / “ 1.746287 , -75.627790 ,
716m
[eters], Forest, trampa Malaise dosel” / “
21.xii.2016
-
04.i.2017
, Y. Ramos-Pastrana ”. “ HOLOTYPE /
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
/ Montoya, Parada-Marín & Ramos-Pastrana 2021 ” [red, handwritten except first line] ( LEUA –00000035890, dissected)
.
PARATYPES .
SURINAME , Para , Mapane area , 5.466 666, -54.683333,
35 m
,
28.v.1963
, P.H. van Doesburg Jr. , Leg. (RMNH-collection, 1 female ); Brokopondo , Brownsberg, 4.933 333, -55.166667,
189m
, Nature reserve, mainly with primary forest,
31.viii–14.ix.2001
, leg. A. Gangadin , Leg. (RMNH-collection, 1 female ). Identified as
Copestylum
SUR-04 by Menno Reemer 2016
.

Differential diagnosis.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
shares the general morphological characters of other known species in the
C. vagum
group.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
is a green yellowish fly, similar in appearance to
C. vagum
,
C. musicanum
, and
C. tenorium
, from which it differs by the gena and face separated by a very broad brown vitta; scutum orange except for the wide medial vitta, which is dark and metallic, ending before the prescutellar region, with the apical margin M-shaped; tibiae dark-brown, except yellow on basal 1/4. Epandrium and cercus black, contrasting with the colour of hypandrium and surstylus, which are orange; epandrium with a dorsal extension, in addition to the surstylus L-shaped, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to small deer antlers in velvet.

Description ( holotype ). MALE. Head
( Figs 1A, C , and D): Face yellowish-orange without a clear central vitta; gena and face separated by a very broad brown vitta; gena orange, orange pruinose, and pilose; dorsal margin of eyes sloping and yellow pilose; lunule brownish-orange; antenna orange, scape and pedicel orange setulose; arista orange, orange pilose. Thorax ( Figs 1B–D ): Scutum orange except for the wide medial vitta, which is dark and metallic, ending before the prescutellar region, with the apical margin M-shaped ( Fig. 1C ); scutum brown pilose on the median dark area, yellow pilose along lateral margins, with pile not much longer at the rear margin; lateral setae orange: two above wing insertion and two on postalar callus; pleuron extensively yellow; scutellum yellow with pre-apical depression, yellow pilose; marginal setae orange-yellow, with two dark brown setae. Wing ( Figs 1B–E , 2B ): Hyaline except for the brown-yellowish pterostigmal spot, costal cell yellowish, bare; wing microtrichose, except for some extensively bare areas basally and centrally, cell bm extensively bare, cell dm bare on anterior 1/3, cell r only slightly bare on basal 1/3 or less, cell CuP bare on anterior 1/3; alula microtrichose, calypter yellowishwhite, border brownish-orange, fringe brownish-orange; plumula yellow-orange; halter yellow-orange, capitulum white. Legs ( Figs 1A–B, D–E ): coxa and trochanter yellow, metafemur extensively orange; tibia dark-brown, except yellow on basal 1/4, black pilose on these areas; tarsomeres 1 and 2 orange, tarsomeres 3–5 black, black pilose. Abdomen ( Figs 1B, D–E , 2A–B ): Mostly yellow-greenish, orange-yellow pilose, first tergum 1 yellow-greenish; terga 2–4 greenish, brownish infuscated apically; terga 3–4 black pilose on apical margin; S1–4 yellowish-green and extensively yellow pilose; male genitalia elongated, extending over the fourth sternum, with epandrium and cercus black, epandrium in lateral view with a dorsal extension, cercus in lateral view, globular and round-tipped; surstylus in lateral view, L-shaped, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to small deer antlers in velvet; superior lobe (Apex of hypandrium) orange, hook-shaped, with a kinked apex strongly curved downward ( Figs 2D–H ).

FEMALE ( Figs 3A–D ; Reemer 2016: 100 , Fig. 15, dorsal habitus). Similar to male except for usual sexual dimorphism, and differing in vertex with a complete brownish transverse macula, extensively dark brown to blackhaired in this area; sternites 4 and 5 yellow.

Etymology. The epithet ‘enriquei’ is a patronym given in memory of Carlos Enrique Giraldo, the grandfather of the first author, a notable, worthy, and noble person of sweet spirit who was like an oak, a very happy man who taught me (ALM) to enjoy and marvel at the small things of the natural world. For him, this beautiful species that flies high as his unforgettable smile and kind way of being, always ready to provide a space and welcome in his home in Anserma, Caldas , Colombia that was always open to everyone.

Taxonomic remarks.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
run to
C. chapadensis
or
C. bequaerti
in the key of Curran (1930 ; couplet 9, p. 6), based on the gena and face separated by a very broad brownish vitta. This work covered most species belonging to the
C. vagum
group.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
would be identified as
C. musicanum
in an unpublished draft key by F.C. Thompson (couplet 13), as it has the tibiae much darker than the femora, terminalia large, cercus elongate, hook-like, extending over the fourth sternum. Using the key of
Ricarte et al . (2015
; couplet 3, p. 52),
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
keys out close to
C. araceorum
and
C. willistoni
, based on the terga 3−4 with yellow marks or completely black, however,
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
lacks a median vitta on the face.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
is also morphologically similar to
C. tenorium
from which it differs by the diagnostic characters listed in Table 1 (See also “Taxonomic notes” under each species in
Ricarte et al . 2015
and keys).

Distribution. The male holotype was collected between 21 December 2016 and
04 February 2017
in a canopy Malaise trap (Rafael & Gorayeb 1982) in a pristine rainforest patch of a conflict territory of limited access and political unrest in Caquetá , Colombia ( Fig. 4A ). The type locality is located at the eastern slope of the Colombian Oriental Cordillera at an altitude of 716 meters above sea level (m a.s.l). Two additional female specimens ( paratypes ) were collected in two sampling events on
28 May 1963
and between
31 August and 14 September 2001
in a nature reserve and primary forest in Northeastern Suriname ( Para and Brokopondo ) between 35 and
189 m a.s.l.
( Fig. 4B ).
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
is probably endemic to the Amazonian rainforest of Colombia and Suriname on the Guyana shield.

Biology.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
is only known from pristine patches in the lowlands of the Amazonian rainforest of Colombia and Suriname ( Fig. 4B ). The specimens were collected using a canopy Malaise trap and sweeping net, which could suggest that the species is associated with both canopy and ground levels in conserved forest.

subSection.paragraph:
A new key to the species of the
C. vagum
group is provided to distinguish the new species
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
from the other eighteen species in the group. The concept of the
C. vagum
group remains unaltered, increasing some novel characters concerning the highly modified genitalia of the new species, where the surstylus is unique and striking with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to small deer antlers in velvet. The modification of the surstylus of
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
could be associated with functional utilities in the mating process, since the surstyli is the structure that grips the female, facilitating the coupling ( Rotheray & Gilbert 2011 ). This novel morphological evidence for
Copestylum
could open the way to new questions about the origin, evolution, and diversification of the richest hoverfly group in the Neotropical region,
Copestylum
.

The distributional patterns of the
C. vagum
group are considerably variable.
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
(Colombian and Suriname ),
C. flukei
,
C. lanei
( Brazil and Colombia ),
C. musicanum
( Brazil and Suriname ),
C. chapadensis
( Brazil , Brazilian Amazon),
C. circe
,
C. curiosum
,
C. rurale
( Brazil ),
C. varichaeta
( Peru ), and
C. tigrinum
( Trinidad ) appear to be restricted to South America.
Copestylum bequaerti
( Guatemala , Mexico ) and
C. cyclops
( Costa Rica ) are only known from Central America. The group also includes widely distributed species such as
C. vagum
( Brazil , Brazilian Amazon, Colombia , Costa Rica , Guyana , Less Antilles, Peru , and Suriname ),
C. virescens
( Colombia , Costa Rica , Guatemala ),
C. araceorum
( Colombia , Costa Rica , and Ecuador ),
C. tenorium
( Colombia , Costa Rica ), and
C. willistoni
( Costa Rica , Trinidad ) which extend from Central to South America.
Copestylum brevifacies
( Argentina , Brazil , Guyana , Suriname ), and
C. mocanum
( Colombia , Brazilian Amazon, Guatemala , Peru , Venezuela ) are exclusive and widely spread in South America.

As shown above, the
C. vagum
group includes narrowly and widely distributed species, with
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
apparently restricted to lowlands in the Amazonian rainforest of Colombia and Suriname , and
C. araceorum
and
C. tenorium
are recorded for the first time in the Colombian Amazonian region. These findings could suggest an apparent lack of sampling effort in the
C. vagum
group so that new expeditions to unexplored areas could eventually result in the estimation of its real distributional range throughout the region.

The description of
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
based on a single male and two females reflects the difficulty of detecting and capturing this species, apparently restricted to Amazonian rainforests. Although we are unable to determine whether the species is really rare or simply difficult to detect, it is notable that the holotype was the only individual found amongst more than 2,363 Syrphidae specimens collected during an extensive six-month sampling, covering a great variety of habitats from lowland and foothills of the Amazon rainforest of Caquetá , Colombia ( 88,965 km ²). This sampling included different sampling methods, with 20 sampling stations distributed throughout the department (
Parada-Marín et al . 2021
). In the same way, only two specimens ( paratypes ) were captured in two localities in Suriname ( 163,820 km ²), despite having carried out an extensive sampling that covered above 50 localities (for details see Reemer 2016 ).
Copestylum enriquei
sp. nov.
is hitherto known only from three localities in the Amazonian rainforests of Colombia and Suriname . Considering the gap between the three known localities where the new species occurs, it seems likely that the species is widespread in intermediate and adjacent areas within the Amazonian region of Brazil , Ecuador , Venezuela , and Peru .

Several syrphid species with restricted range have been described on the basis of few specimens ( Mengual 2013 ;
Morales et al . 2013
;
Montoya et al . 2017
; Montoya & Wolff 2020 ). In this regard,
Lim et al . (2012)
pointed out that “rare” species are common in taxonomic revisions and that collecting in the least explored areas may often lead to singletons becoming “double”, accompanied by the discovery of additional new species, based on “singletons” (
Montoya et al . 2021
), or the finding of new distributional records, with the expansion of geographic range such as the recent record of the rare species
Cepa apeca Thompson, 2007
in the Colombian Andean-Amazonian region (
Parada-Marín et al . 2021
). In this sense, although nothing is known about the habitat preferences of
C. enriquei
sp. nov.
, the discovery of new biological data about the breeding sites could explain its apparent rarity and restricted affinity to the Amazonian rainforest, critical to recognize its vulnerability and conservation status.

Financial support was provided by the Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación, Project 1131712497- 49-2015. ALM thanks to the ‘Fondo Nacional de Financiamiento para la Ciencia, la Tecnología y la Innovación Francisco José de Caldas’ and Colciencias (Convocatorias 745–2016) to the project “Las moscas de las flores ( Diptera : Syrphidae ) como bioindicadoras de la calidad del ambiente en los ecosistemas altoandinos del noroccidente de Colombia ” funded by the Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación de la República de Colombia and Colfuturo PhD. Grant (Becas Colciencias Doctorados Nacionales, convocatoria 647 de 2014 ). Thanks are due to Eric Córdoba for his assistance in taking additional photographs of male holotype . We express our special thanks to Menno Reemer for sharing his pictures of the two female specimens from RMNH. We also thank Antonio Ricarte and anonymous reviewers for the thorough review and helpful comments that improved the quality of this manuscript.
